comments.commentBody:
Apparently the Koch brothers realized their Tea Party is beginning to get out of control on this issue which potentially may cause self inflicted damage (both political and economic). Yves Smith wrote about it a couple of days ago.

http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2013/01/republicans-backing-away-from-deb...

It's worth thinking about *why* you were wrong on this one.

As someone who usually sides with Krugman over Klein, the latter was totally right in the last debate. The question is why.

My own analysis: The tea party Republicans may have gotten a bit out of control, but the majority of the party is still beholden mainly to the rich, who lose the most even in a brief semi-default. The rich aren't crazy, merely extremely greedy. Don't forget that even Republicans are a diverse coalition -- and it matters exactly what the percentages in that coalition are.
In Greek and Roman mythology, Cerberus was a three-headed dog that guarded the gates of hell, keeping sinners from escaping. Perfect name for this diabolical company.
As it now stands, it seems far fewer of the weapons in question will be sold, but at a much higher price. Is that whats called a market correction?

So if understand correctly those happy Cerberus investors, the more automatic weapons are sold, the more money they will make and the more satisfied they will be, even though it means more Americans will be killed while innocently going about their business. As usual, American short-sightedness, focused only on today's monetary returnns, giving no thought to the longer term implications of what we are doing to ourselves as a society and how much the medical and psychiatric treatment of the victims and their famiies are costing us, not to mention depriving us of the dead's talents and skills.
Perhaps if Cerberus included in their annual reports to investors photos of the massacres their products cause, they would stop being so narrow-minded and so money-focused. Don't we have other ways in this country of earning honest dollars? Do we have to encourage needless deaths to make profits? God, we are a sick nation.

The reason people believe that printing money leads to inflation is because it sure sounds like that should be the case in a common sense way.  Recent history shows that economic reality doesn't equate to kitchen table household budgeting, but even the President has used that analogy.  So, it's not just the right-wing media that have been perpetuating the greater myth of impending fiscal doom, and not necessarily for malicious intent.  And when the legend becomes fact, print the legend.

Interesting article.
No doubt the left wing has won the political game.They control the media and can easily "spin" whatever they want and have their surrogates attack their opponents. This gave Obama his victory.
The problem will be in the implementation of a welfare state and it's longevity.
Their basic philosophy is flawed and has not stood the economic test of time.
The obvious examples of Greece,Spain,U.K etc.stand out.
When people receive welfare, they look at ways of maximizing their windfall and their desire for work diminishes. This attitude goes inter-generational.The more they fail,the more they will be rewarded.
In France, the new socialist leader increased taxes to 75% and a lot of it's young entrepreneurs left the country. Many went to Singapore, with a flat tax of 15%. France will not only lose tax revenue, jobs but also impetus. The welfare recipients will still have their hands out but there will be less revenue to pay them. France can do the same as the U.S and borrow money, could print money,raise taxes but all of this short term and a day of reckoning will happen.
You are correct, there needs to be a balance but big government will not be able to supply the balance.
Bureaucrats are rewarded for their inefficiency. The bigger their department,the bigger their salary and lifetime pensions.
Another example is China,where the middle class is growing at a fast rate.
More regulation and more government spending,will exacerbate the decline of the middle class.

An index fund by definition does not discriminate, you're investing in a section of the market, the top 500, small cap , whatever. But the pension funds choose investments one at a time and chose to invest in Cerberus. I think it's reasonable to ask that they not make certain investments. In fact there are funds that invest based on social responsibility, "green" investments, etc. You could try to pressure your fund for choices - you do get to choose the kind of investment in many of them.
How true is that.  A liar from the start.  Then it snowballs into wealth, people laud you, and you can't stop - like a Bernie Madoff of the cycling world.

>

and this is exactly why American presidents will always be able to sell their wars. Present it as a heroic rescue of millions of damsels and their equally helpless men folk in distress. Only the tough Americans can and should live their life without government handouts, without entitlement programs (that they pay for), without government run healthcare, ....

We ought to ignore Lance Armstrong. Forget about him. He's just a con man.

Then again, he's also a narcissist, and this country is just overrun with little Lances, a "hero" for our times, scheming a narrative that will enable him to sell running shoes, or t-shirts . . .or whatever . . . and get rich quick.

Tim, you've described the situation here in Japan pretty well and made some good points, except I would say that the US has had no less malaise over the past few decades, with no fewer young people unemployed or underemployed, and with far too many American kids forced to get their educations through the military.

ATNO SINGLET point, whatsoever, did I ETHER WALTZ or SAIL through this SATXWDP by MISTER David Q, consequently, describing it as EASYPEASY, ASFARAS I'm concerned, is EELY IRONIC, not to mention BAZAAR!
But don't GOBI what I say, I've made my PICTS, now judge for yourself!

"THERITZ is silence!"

TILT next time, Howie

Health Insurance is just being preventive and keeping oneself on the safer side. One can take a judgement on it s affordability under critical circumstances when it is required urgently.Moreover cost of the treatment plays a vital role  when we talk about affordable health Insurance.

Mr Hoffman's flawed prognosticatings aside, In the final analysis Cal you must ask yourself this question : Which is less painful ( for you) ?  Losing to the Ravens this weekend, or losing another Super Bowl in 2 weeks?

Just to keep it all in perspective, let's not overlook the fact that our blogger Mr. Hoffman picked the Packers, Seahawks, and Broncos to win last weekend.  That's right, he was wrong on three of the four playoff games, so I wouldn't get overly excited about any predictions he cares to make on this Sunday's action.  The only game he called right  a week ago was by picking for the Patriots, and that's the only one he's called wrong this weekend, by picking against them.
Well that should make Tuesday's market opening VERY interesting.

I think that's easy to say in hindsight, but President Obama hadn't been known previously to be a strong negotiator, and made significant compromises the last time it became necessary to raise the debt limit in order to pay the bills that Congress had incurred.  So the present outcome was not a foregone conclusion.

Growth is coming.  We are in the despair kill the bear phase of the cycle.    In 20 years this angst about future costs will  be a distant memory.  Too much handwringing and focus on the wrong  priorities.  Our exreme labor and cash (banks and large corps) surpluses are an opportunity.   I say to the 1%, Carpe Diem .  Hire the labor and start producing more more more

On the other hand, Obama might have been emboldened into not negotiating with the Republicans over raising the debt ceiling once it had become obvious that Democrats were very concerned that he might wimp out.

The Senate Democrats even wrote Obama a letter stating that he shouldn't cave in without at least trading Social Security cuts for raising the debt ceiling. So even they were concerned that Obama would fold like a tent.

I found it interesting that Rep Camp had to walk through a blow by blow account of what would happen without a debt ceiling increase.  The next lesson would be on the need for financial stability in an economic crises.  You need to crawl before you walk.  Walk before you run.  I'm glad Rep Camp taught his caucus how to stand.
Good grief.

Your suggestion means marginal college-eligible students would face a fish-or-cut-bait testing hurdle right away. The potential problem is that the basic courses (not even remedial, but basic) typically involve helping students learn what they need to know to improve. This typically involves intensive, hands-on personal interaction. The model of online courses, even with extra teaching assistants for interactive help, can't and won't offer anything like intensive help. That's the whole point of MOOCs; they're mass courses, not intensively personal interaction courses. Sink or swim.

The large schools are not "messed up" . They are operated like businesses, with corporate goals. Their main goals are self-preservation, growth of endowment, and increase in salaries for management and administrator, similar to any other large corporation. The economic power and income from some of their endowments dwarf any educational operation, leading to frequent disagreements between faculty and administration, demonstrating the divergence of their goals. Any education that occurs is a minor PR effort, sophisticated advertising that gets them tax-free status, exemption from anti-trust laws, tax-free donation status.
They are wrong in our opinion (yours and mine) because we have a different model of what they are supposed to be, in our minds. We don't think universities should be like that, which makes our difficulty greater-- if it were as simple as "messed up", it would be easier to change. A mess can be cleaned up if all parties agree. Powerful interests do not agree with us, and the universities hold our children's future as their hostages.

'Blaming women and/or not believing them is an old old old story.'

Agreed. But this is a new story. There was no woman.

Blaming women and/or not believing them is an old old old story. It's not a football story per se. It's not a college story per se. Remember Strauss-Kahn? It must have been the case that the woman had an ulterior motive. etc etc etc etc....

Our fine upstanding gents running for public office or in public office "know" that women can't get pregnant from rape etc etc etc. If "she" didn't cry bloody murder and scratch the man's eyes out she must have "consented." That kind of reasoning was even applied by a judge about a non-verbal young woman with cerebral palsy in a wheelchair.

At my own advanced age of 70 I'm reading Susan Brownmiller's 1975 book "Against Our Will:Men, Women, and Rape," 1975, for the first time.
Chapters - 1. Mass Psychology of Rape;
2. In the Beginning was the Law;
3. War. WWI, WWII, Bangladesh, Vietnam;
4. Riots, Pogroms and Revolution;
5. Two Studies in American History. Indians, Slavery;
6. The Police-Blotter Rapist - Pairs, Groups and Gangs; "Gratuitous Acts, Extravagent Defilements"; Rape-Murder;
7. A Question of Race;
8. Power: Institution and Authority - Prison Rape: The Homosexual Experience. Police Rape, The Sexual Abuse of Children;
9. The Myth of the Heroic Rapist;
10. Victims: The Setting. The Conscious Rape Fantasy; The Beautiful Victim; "Blonde Ex-Showgirl Slain in Hotel Suite", Confessions: "He Made Me Do It!";
11. Victims: The Crime;
12. Women Fight Back.

Enraging.

Oh? A college football team run like a business has shown a blatant callousness for outsiders in the name of self-preservation?  Maybe I'll figure out how to put up a profile pic on here so I can have a shocked expression.

Nice Jane!

Your Donizetti double-reference, from mad scene to love potion, is priceless.

There's an opportunity for a company to create a less lethal self defense weapon, that perhaps does not inflict as much damage. Rubber bullets, lower muzzle velocities - I'm sure army medics can help design this less lethal weapon. This would be a great opportunity for a new company. Just something harmful enough to put someone on their back while the person who was threatened makes their escape.

Unless guns are really about death, and not self defense.

@pepper_95 Indian women marrying foreign men from the early 20th century? Hmm

*In* the early 20th century, though, such women could have been counted on the fingers of ET's one hand.

There were of course many Indian women in the previous centuries, especially the early 19th and late 18th, who either married, or lived with, or bore children to British men (in the days before the Suez canal had opened and before single British women made their way to India to marry). The Anglo-Indian (formerly Eurasian) community was a result of such pairings. Whether the women had free choice, is another story.

@pepper_95

If the unprecedentedly educated female progeny this teeny weeny new India is still upholding a tired old vision of patrimony and matrimony, I say, let them squirm.
Ouch. Sorry you're going through a hard time, Atit. Marriage may definitely not be for you.
